selected_quotes: Atoms cooled to 50 pK (trillionths of a degree above absolute 0) using matter-wave lens #PRL
Rubidium atoms used to record coldest temperature ever ~ 50 trillionths of 1 K: and (paper)
50 pK Rb atoms. A new record for the coldest temperature achieved! Congrats Mark.

citation.title: Matter Wave Lensing to Picokelvin Temperatures

news.title: Atomic telescope brings atoms to standstill
news.summary: May let researchers see quantum to classical transition.

news.title: Rubidium atoms used to record coldest temperature — ever
news.summary: A swarm of rubidium atoms has been cooled to about 50 trillionths of a kelvin, making it the coldest substance ever measured.

news.title: Ultracold Experiment Could Solve One of Physics’s Biggest Contradictions
news.summary: By chilling atoms so they come to a standstill, scientists may have figured out a way to observe the transition from quantum to classical realms.

reddit.title: Matter Wave Lensing to Picokelvin Temperatures (arXiv link in comments)

facebook.title: Matter Wave Lensing to Picokelvin Temperatures
facebook.summary: In quantum mechanics, matter has particle-like and wave-like properties. Now, scientists have lensed the wave-like property of atoms to cool them to an unprecedented temperature: 50 trillionths of a degree above absolute zero. journals.aps.org

facebook.title: Matter Wave Lensing to Picokelvin Temperatures
facebook.summary: How cool is this? VERY cool.

facebook.title: Matter Wave Lensing to Picokelvin Temperatures
facebook.summary: In quantum mechanics, matter has particle-like and wave-like properties. Now, scientists have lensed the wave-like property of atoms to cool them to an unprecedented temperature: 50 trillionths of a degree above absolute zero.

facebook.title: Matter Wave Lensing to Picokelvin Temperatures
facebook.summary: An optical dipole field is used as a collimating lens to cool Rubidium atoms to record-low kinetic temperatures of 50 picokelvin.

facebook.title: Matter Wave Lensing to Picokelvin Temperatures
facebook.summary:
In quantum mechanics, matter has particle-like and wave-like properties. Now, scientists have lensed the wave-like property of atoms to cool them to an unprecedented temperature: 50 trillionths of a degree above absolute zero.

Text Courtesy: APS Physics
